snippet: Readers debate the adequacy of Apple’s wages.

The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes the Chrome mobile browser jumping to No. 1 among Apple apps, a revisiting of the Microsoft chief's initial react...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes the Chrome mobile browser jumping to No. 1 among Apple apps, a revisiting of the Microsoft chief's initial reaction to the iPhone and an essay on the latest new products from Google.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Paint-On Batteries and Facebook's 'Want'

snippet: Love it or hate it, Apple’s touch-screen handset has made an impact on some aspect of your life — whether it’s how you work, communicate with friends, plan your day or read the news.
abstract: Love it or hate it, Apple’s touch-screen handset has made an impact on some aspect of your life — whether it’s how you work, communicate with friends, plan your day or read the news.

headline.main: The iPhone Turns 5. Here's What It Wrought.

snippet: I am not damaged goods; I'm changed by my childhood, but I am not broken.
abstract: I am not damaged goods; I'm changed by my childhood, but I am not broken.

headline.main: I Refuse to Let Child Abuse Define Me

snippet: Research in Motion announced it was further delaying the introduction of its new line of BlackBerry smartphones until 2013, a setback that has further eroded confidence in the company. The latest delay, which was announced along with a $518 millio...
abstract: Research in Motion announced it was further delaying the introduction of its new line of BlackBerry smartphones until 2013, a setback that has further eroded confidence in the company. The latest delay, which was announced along with a $518 million loss in the company's first quarter, increased doubts among analysts and investors about RIM's future

headline.main: Daily Report: Another Setback for RIM

snippet: Nearly half of recently retired officers in a survey said they had “personal knowledge” of crime-report manipulation, but the Police Department questioned the study’s methodology.
abstract: Anonymous survey of nearly 2,000 retired New York City Police Officers finds that manipulation of crime reports has long been part of the culture of the department; Police Dept officials criticize the methodology of the study, led by Prof Eli B Silverman of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and question the reliability of the findings.

headline.main: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds

snippet: A roundup of noteworthy events taking place in New York and the region in celebration of the Fourth of July holiday.

headline.main: Fourth of July Celebrations From June 29-July 4

snippet: Now in its 11th year, the New York Asian Film Festival offers more than 50 films from 10 countries encompassing some of the world’s most vital film industries.
abstract: Mike Hale notes some of the standout films in the 11th annual New York Asian Film Festival, including Yeun Sang-ho's animated feature The King of Pigs.
